title: 2022 South Korean presidential election
deleted: *[[HuhKyung-young]], partyfounder and 2018 candidate for Seoul Mayor, 1997 and 2007 [[:ko:민주공화당 (대한민국, 1997년)|Republican]] presidential candidate.<ref>https://news.joins.com/article/24124928</ref>

The [[Progressive Party (South Korea, 2017)|Progressive Party]] ([[Korean language|Korean]]: 진보당) is a [[left-wing politics|left-wing]], [[Progressivism|progressive]] party of [[labor movement|labor]] that was founded originally as the '''Minjung Party''' on 15 October 2017.
*[[Kim Jae-yeon (politician)|Kim Jae-yeon]], former member of the [[National Assembly]] (2012–2014).<ref>https://www.hani.co.kr/arti/politics/assembly/1006592.html</ref>

*[[KimDong-yeon]], former[[Deputy Prime Minister of South Korea]] and Minister of Economy and Finance (2017 to 2018)<ref name="As ex-Prosecutor General Yoon 'falt"/><ref>https://en.yna.co.kr/view/AEN20210820005300315?section=national/politics</ref>(announced on 20 August)

title: 2022 South Korean presidential election
added: During the primary campaign, observers noted that the presidential campaign was going down as the most negative campaign in South Korea's recent history, as the candidates were described to be busy mudslinging at each other and there was no evidence that the candidates were competing on the basis of values, platforms or policies. A Hankyoreh commentary said PPP candidates like Yoo Seong-min, Won Hee-ryong, and Choi Jae-hyung, and Lee Nak-yeon and Chung Sye-kyun on the Democratic side struggled in their respective party primaries as they were too "elite" and too "respectable". The commentary also attributed to the success of Lee Jae-myung, the Democratic candidate, and Hong Jun-pyo and Yoon Seok-youl on the PPP side due to the increasing tendency to vote with the heart instead of the brain and to prioritize candidate attributes and authentic over competence.<ref>{{cite news |date= 26 September 2021|title= The golden era of bad guys running for president in S. Korea|url=https://www.hani.co.kr/arti/english_edition/e_national/1012702.html|access-date= 14 October 2021}}</ref>

title: 2022 South Korean presidential election
added: During the primary campaign, observers noted that the presidential campaign was going down as the most negative campaign in South Korea's recent history, as the candidates were described to be busy mudslinging at each other and there was no evidence that the candidates were competing on the basis of values, platforms or policies. A Hankyoreh commentary said PPP candidates like Yoo Seong-min, Won Hee-ryong, and Choi Jae-hyung, and Lee Nak-yeon and Chung Sye-kyun on the Democratic side struggled in their respective party primaries as they were too "elite" and too "respectable". The commentary also attributed to the success of Lee Jae-myung, the Democratic candidate, and Hong Jun-pyo and Yoon Seok-youl on the PPP side due to the increasing tendency to vote with the heart instead of the brain and to prioritize candidate attributes andauthenticityover competence.<ref>{{cite news |date= 26 September 2021|title= The golden era of bad guys running for president in S. title: 2022 South Korean presidential election
added: The three main contenders, Lee for the Democratic Party, and Hong Jun-pyo and Yoon on the PPP side, were reported to have record low favourability ratings according to approval ratings compiled by Gallup Korea. Lee, has an approval rating of only 34%, while Yoon's rating was at just 30% and Hong Joon-pyo, at 28%. In contrast, President Moon Jae-in had a positive rating of 47% while running for election in 2017. <ref>{{cite news |date= 14 October 2021|title= South Korea’s Mud-Slinging Primary Campaign Nears End|url=https://www.voanews.com/a/south-korea-s-mud-slinging-primary-campaign-nears-end/6270150.html|access-date= 14 October 2021}}</ref>.
